title: Boris Johnson ‘refuses to face scrutiny’ by pulling out of committee hearing
text:
Boris Johnson pulled out of an important committee hearing (Picture: Getty Images Europe)

The Prime Minister has been accused of ‘refusing to face detailed scrutiny’ after pulling out of an important committee meeting at late notice.

In a handwritten letter to Commons Liaison Committee chair Dr Sarah Wollaston, Boris Johnson asked to postpone his appearance for ‘five or six months’ – after being accused of cancelling twice before.

Slamming the decision on Twitter, Dr Wollaston said she was ‘astonished’ by the move and accused Mr Johnson of ‘refusing to be held to account’.

The former Conservative, who recently defected to the Lib Dems, wrote: ‘Frankly, I am astonished that, at such short notice, you are refusing to face detailed scrutiny from select committee chairs tomorrow morning.

‘This is the third time that you have postponed or cancelled.

‘I have already conveyed the Committee’s deep disappointment that you did not appear on Wednesday 11th September, despite your suggestion of that date and your later reassurance that you would keep that commitment.’

Dr Sarah Wollaston (R) with Lib Dem leader Jo Swinson (L) (Picture: AFP)

Mr Johnson’s letter (Picture: @sarahwollaston)

The handwritten note was posted on Twitter (Picture: @sarahwollaston)

Dr Wollaston’s response continued: ‘Our role is to ask you detailed questions of behalf of the public and we planned to do so on Brexit, climate change, health and social care.

‘It is unacceptable that you are refusing to be held to account.’

The Prime Minister had been due to face questioning by the Committee, made up of select committee chairmen, at Westminster.

In his letter, Mr Johnson wrote: ‘Dear Sarah, I promised that I will come to the Liaison Committee and I will keep that promise but I am afraid I must now focus on delivering Brexit in the difficult circumstances in which we now find ourselves, and I believe I would be of greater value if I could postpone to a fixed date nearer five or six months after I became PM, so that my appearance took place after roughly the same period in office as Gordon Brown, David Cameron & Theresa May.

‘I do hope you will understand’.

Dr Wollaston’s response (Picture: @sarahwollaston)

MPs from across the political spectrum have since weighed in to criticise the Mr Johnson.

Labour’s Yvette Cooper labelled the move ‘disgraceful’, while Conservative Tom Tugendhat described it as ‘very surprising and disappointing’.

The committee hearings – which normally take place three times a year – are an opportunity for members to put detailed questions to the Prime Minister on selected policy areas.

description: Prime Minister stands accused of 'refusing to be held to account’ by 'astonished' Commons Liaison Committee chairwoman Dr Sarah Woolaston.
